bibl.title: Letter from Miguel Roldan to Philip Showalter Hench, January 11, 1954

div1.p: Roldan is working on a biography of Finlay that will demonstrate Finlay's major role in the discovery of the cause of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Miguel Roldan to Philip Showalter Hench, January 11, 1954
div1.opener:
Name PHILIP S. HENCH, M.D.
Street & No. MAYO CLINIC
City ROCHESTER State MINNESOTA
When Replying Sign Your Full Name and
Address. Give Inmate's Full Name and
Number
2189, DRAWER
STORMVILL
CORRESPONDENCE
DEPARTMENT
CENSOR
1
JAN 12 1954
Date Jan. 11, 1954
My dear doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I am in receipt of your kind letter of Dec. 24th to which I did not
reply earlier because it was probably caught in the holiday rush and it arrived considerably
late. I am very happy that you sent not only the material I wanted on yellow fever but
the pamphlet on Cortisone, and I wish to thank you for both.

For quite some time I had known about your interest in locating the
exact spot of Camp Lazear, in Marianao, but the details in your address before Alpha Omega
Alpha have come to elucidate a point in my mind as to why was General Kean so insistent
in his letters to Drs. Anglés and Domínguez about the exact location of the campsite. It was
evidently to back your stand on the subject. Your noticing the abandoned RR spur to La Playa
in addition to been a keen observation demonstrates your sincere interest in this matter.

After I wrote to the Librarian at the Mayo Clinic in an effort to
obtain the details I sought about you, and before receiving your reply, I read in a Cuban
daily that you had been promoted to Commander of the National Order of Carlos J. Finlay and
it gave me much pleasure since this is a small way to show the Cuban's appreciation of
your friendship and interest in the little nation.

For the past eleven years I have been compiling material for a biography
of Dr. Finlay and I am now engaged in the actual task. So very little has been truthfully
said about him that the tremendous importance of his trail blazing has been lost in the
dust of Dr. Reed's chariot as far as nearly all of the yellow fever literature in the United
is concerned. And this is a grave injustice which the American people would not have
countenanced had they been given the true historical facts from the beginning. Had there never
been a Carlos Finlay the equation of yellow fever would have been solved by some other man
at some other time but it would not have been solved by Major Reed in some 30 or 40 days
of actual work in 1900. This much is true and that is what I am endeavoring to demonstrate,
that the the greatest medical discovery in the history of the New World, and even one of the
greatest in the annals of the medical sciences of all times, rests squarely upon the solid
foundation which Finlay built for the other great men to work on.

In this connection I am also happy to know that you are collecting
documents such as those of Mrs. Lazear and Mrs. Reed, etc. To have all of these papers together
with the Army records for posterity to go to as a source of authentic data is a most praise-
worthy task for which you are to be congratulated.- Perhaps I will need some additional
information which I will request from you, if you permit me to do so.

I hope that you find your stay in Cuba a pleasant one and I beg
to remain
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours Miguel Roldan Miguel Roldan,
2189, Drawer B,
Stormville, N.Y.
